skills.name: Form expressions from situations described in words
Describe the meaning of algebraic terms with no powers
Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention
Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention involving powers

explanations.A: Not quite! You have successfully learnt when an expression involves multiplication, even when 'x' doesn't appear! :) You just need to remember the order of operations: multiplications come before additions. You'll be ready next time! :)
explanations.B: Not quite! ac actually means a x c rather than a + c. You'll be ready next time! :)
explanations.C: Not quite! You have successfully learnt when an expression involves multiplication, even when 'x' doesn't appear! :) You just need to remember the order of operations: multiplications come before additions. You'll be ready next time! :)
explanations.D: ac means "a multiplied by c". We also need to remember the correct order of operations, so we must do this multiplication first. So, we add 5 to a multiplied by c.

explanations.A: This answer is correct - ab means "a multiplied by b", and following the order of operations, that happens first, and then we can do 3 plus the answer of a multiplied by b
explanations.B: Not quite! ab actually means a x b rather than a + b. You'll be ready next time! :)
explanations.C: Not quite! You have successfully learnt when an expression involves multiplication, even when 'x' doesn't appear! :) You just need to remember the order of operations: multiplications come before additions. You'll be ready next time! :)
explanations.D: Not quite! You have successfully learnt when an expression involves multiplication, even when 'x' doesn't appear! :) You just need to remember the order of operations: multiplications come before additions. You'll be ready next time! :)

explanations.A: Subtracting 5 from h is written as h - 5.Then we need to multiply all of that by 6, so we put it into brackets, with the six in front 6(h - 5).
explanations.B: Not quite! You have successfully shown how to indicate multiplying in algebraic expressions :). Reconsider what 'subtract five from h' means and you'll get there next time. You were close! :) In future, be careful about which way round you write subtractions to get the marks your learning deserves! :)
explanations.C: Not quite! Think about the order it means to say 'subtract five from h', if it was subtract 5 from 7, how would you write that? Also, remember that we don't always need a multiplication sign, is there a more mathematical way we could write this than x 6? You'll be ready next time! :)
explanations.D: So close! Your answer is actually correct in that this is what the description means, the expression can be written even more simply though, see if you can find the absolute best version; you were very nearly right! :)

explanations.A: Not quite! The expression is written well, but remember to think about which number is adding and which is multiplying. You'll get there next time! :)
explanations.B: This answer is correct! Adding four to h can be written as h+4 but also as 4+h, because they both give the same answer. Then we need to multiply all of that by 3, so we put it into brackets, with the three in front and no multiplication sign as we know 3 in front of the brackets means we have to multiply! :)
explanations.C: So close; great try! :) This can be written even more mathematically, can we write it in a different way where we don't need a multiplication sign? You'll get there next time! :)
explanations.D: So close; great try! :) This can be written even more mathematically, is there one part of your answer that could go in a different place perhaps? You'll get there next time! :)

explanations.A: You are so close here! :) Just have a little think about how we usually write y x 5, it needs to look different enough from y to the power of 5 so it can't be confused. You'll get it next time! :)
explanations.B: Not quite! Reconsider which variables (letters) and numbers are being multiplied together here. You were close! :)
explanations.C: 5y + bh is the correct way to write this :) Following the order of operations, do the multiplications first and keep them separate, remembering that y x 5 is the same as 5 x y, so is best written as 5y, and then putting the addition sign in-between :)
explanations.D: Not quite! Try re-reading the calculation again, not all the symbols are the same :)

explanations.A: You are so close here! :) Just have a little think about how we usually write b x 3, it needs to look different enough from b to the power of 3 so it can't be confused. You'll get it next time! :)
explanations.B: xy + 3b is the correct way to write this :) Following the order of operations, do the multiplications first and keep them separate, remembering that b x 3 is the same as 3 x b, so is best written as 3b, and then putting the addition sign in-between :) xy is the same as yx, but us mathematicians like alphabetical order! :)
explanations.C: Not quite! Reconsider which variables (letters) and numbers are being multiplied together here. You were close! :)
explanations.D: Not quite! Try re-reading the calculation again as not all the symbols are the same :)

explanations.A: You're not quite there yet - fantastic work removing the multiplication symbols, try putting them in alphabetical order with the number at the beginning and think about if there is a better way to write gg or gxg and you'll get there next time! :)
explanations.B: You're close but have a little bit more to do! Multiplications can be done in any order, but when writing them we like to do numbers first and then put the letters in alphabetical order, have another think :)
explanations.C: The correct answer is C. The number comes first, followed by the letters in alphabetical order and using powers instead of repeating the same letter. So gxg becomes g² :)
explanations.D: Great try! :) This answer is so close, but there is just one more thing to do! Can gg be written better? (more like lll has?)

explanations.A: Great try! :) This answer is so close, but there is just one more thing to do! Can ggg be written better? (more like ll has?)
explanations.B: This answer is correct :) The number comes first, followed by the letters in alphabetical order and using powers instead of repeating the same letter. So gxgxg becomes g³ :)
explanations.C: You're not quite there yet - fantastic work removing the multiplication symbols, try putting them in alphabetical order with the number at the beginning and think about if there is a better way to write ggg or gxgxg and you'll get there next time! :)
explanations.D: You're close but have a little bit more to do! Multiplications can be done in any order, but when writing them we like to do numbers first and then put the letters in alphabetical order, have another think :)

explanations.A: So close! Have another think about which number is being divided :)
explanations.B: There is a better way to write this, try thinking about what the divide symbol also looks like :)
explanations.C: This answer is correct :) l is being divided by m, so m is the divisor and is written as the denominator (bottom of the fraction)
explanations.D: Not quite, this is the algebraic convention for "l x m", see if you can think of another way to show divide. You'll be ready next time! :)

explanations.A: This answer is correct :) b is being divided by a, so a is the divisor and is written as the denominator (bottom of the fraction)
explanations.B: Not quite. You have changed the order of the division. Can we write it as a fraction instead? :)
explanations.C: So close! Have another think about which number is being divided :)
explanations.D: Not quite, this is the algebraic convention for "b x a", see if you can think of another way to show divide. You'll be ready next time! :)
